issue.title: Options dialog not showing conf file
issue.body:
Installed bitcoin core on Windows 10. Changed the data directory to d:\bitcoin. Clicked Settings > Options > Open Configuration File. It opened a blank file for me and saved it in the data directory. I went back and updated the conf file with some defaults. And restarted bitcoin core. The debug log (attached), shows that it is reading my conf file. But when I open the GUI (screen shot attached), it shows the conf file as being "none".

**Expected behavior**

Expect that the conf file from which conf settings are being applied, should also be displayed in the GUI, so I have assurance that my settings have taken effect.

**Actual behavior**

It says "none" for my conf file.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7054246/127372409-30b509ac-8872-4e50-9881-7725709c6d33.png)


**To reproduce**

I suppose it should be reproducible if somebody does the same steps on windows as described above.

**System information**

Bitcoin core version v0.21.1 downloaded from bitcoin.org

System: Dell Optiplex 3010 i5 Windows 10.

Debug log:

events.body:
Hi @asifshiraz! I believe the issue raised by you is a design feature misinterpreted as a bug. The Note mentioned above in the dialogue says: > _The Options set in **this** dialogue are overridden by the command line or in the configuration file._ Focus on _**this**_ It does not say it reflects the name of the config file used for running the node. What it actually shows is a list of all the options relevant to that particular dialogue box and nothing else. Coming back to the debug log attached by you. As it appears, the config file read by your node is bitcoin.conf (present at the data directory) and the options present in there are `rpcpassword=****`, `rpcuser=****`, `server="1"` and `txindex="1"`, none of which are relevant to the options dialogue box. Also, no options were passed as command-line arguments. If you had added any options (in config file or as command-line arguments) relevant to that dialogue box, they would have been listed instead of _none_. I'll write an experiment that might clear the doubt further. - Add `par=-1` to bitcoin.conf file (located at `D:\bitcoin\bitcoin.conf`) - run `src/qt/bitcoin-qt -printtoconsole -par=1 -upnp -server=1 -rpcuser=x` (Dont worry! All of these are safe options and wont affect any functioning) - Open the dialogue box : Settings > Options You'll notice, although you added `par=-1` in your config file, it shows `-par=1` on the dialogue box. It is because the
**command-line argument overrides** the option value added in the config file. You will also notice there are only two options (`-par=1` and `-upnp`) out of the four options you added as command-line arguments because only those two are relevant to that dialogue box. I hope this clears out your doubt. Attaching Screenshots for your reference. | No option in bitcoin.conf,
No Command-Line arg | `-par=-1` option in bitcoin.conf,
No Command-Line arg | `par=-1` option in bitcoin.conf,
`-par=1 -upnp -server=1 -rpcuser=x` as Command-Line args | |-------------|---------------|---------------| | ![Screenshot 2021-08-01 at 12 11 39 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54016434/127749801-c2dc7ee1-f311-457a-8925-8928462c47f0.png) | ![Screenshot 2021-08-01 at 12 11 09 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54016434/127749800-7b598436-cc62-4315-8282-c00725007d72.png) | ![Screenshot 2021-08-01 at 12 15 14 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54016434/127749802-ae23c61d-b107-4e2d-bc39-aaa06c1607d4.png) | Do let me know in case of any further query :)
